title: Kyoto - Arashiyama Monkey Park and Bamboo Grove
content:
Today I wanted to do something a bit different, so I decided to go to Arashiyama to see the monkey park, and also revisit the bamboo grove (this time in better light).

The monkey park turned out to be more enjoyable than I was hoping - it’s a natural area that is reached by a mild 10-15 minute hike up a mountain on the edge of Kyoto. There is only one main building once you reach the top where the monkeys live, and that is used for visitors to feed monkeys if they want - the monkeys are free to roam around the mountainside, and people just visit them in their natural habitat. It was a really nice change to the usual enclosure-based “zoo” type experience, which meant you got to see families of monkeys playing and scampering about, and others cleaning each other, and others being inquisative of the people. I really did enjoy spending time watching them! Also the view was pretty fantastic!

Since I was nearby, I wanted to go to the bamboo grove next, to see if it was as impressive as I remembered it. This was about 10 mins or so from the entrance to the monkey park, and when I arrived, I was a bit disappointed because of the crowds. The grove itself was still just as nice to see (it was even a little more impressive with more daylight), but with all the people visiting and stopping to take photos all over the path, it didn’t have the same impact as last time. Also, there were now signs scattered about saying not to sit and lean and park bikes along the path, which also kinda ruined the feel. I don’t recall that from last time, so I suspect the popularity of the place has boomed and these measures have been put in place to try and keep it managable.

Even though the bamboo grove wasn’t as enjoyable of an experience as I had hoped, it was still decent, and the monkey park more than made up for it!

The afternoon is in the next post!
